facts.text: The respondent was in the service of the appellant-bank's branch at Calcutta and worked as an assistant cashier.
On June 17, 1961, one Shankerlal applied for telegraphic transfer of Rs. 4,000/- from Calcutta to Sujangarh and handed over currency notes of Rs. 100/- each to the respondent.
As the respondent was counting the notes, Shankerlal remembered that he had given 41 notes instead of 40 to the respondent and requested him to return the bundle of notes for verification.
The respondent refused to return the notes saying that the amount given to him was Rs. 4,000/- and notes Rs. 4,100/-.
Shankerlal went back to his shop and verified that he had taken 41 notes instead of 40 and had thus handed over one note of Rs. 100/- extra to the respondent.
Shankerlal came back to the bank and complained to the Manager about this.

The manager ordered the chief cashier to close the cash in the hands of the respondent and to check the amount in his hand with the books. The chief cashier found on checking that there was one note of Rs. 100/- extra with the respondent.
The manager asked the respondent to hand over the extra note but the respondent refused to do so saying that it belonged to him. In explanation he said that it had been given to him by his mother.

The manager immediately took steps to verify this statement and deputed the chief cashier along with another person to the respondent's house to make necessary inquiries. But at the house of the respondent both his mother and father said that they had not given a hundred-rupee note to the respondent.

Thereafter the respondent was told what his parents had said and asked what he had to say further. The respondent then came out with another story that the note was given to him by a tenant of the building in which he lived. He gave out the name of the tenant as Mondal.
The manager again sent the same persons to make enquiries from Mondal but it was found that there was no person of the name of Mondal in that building.
The bank therefore decided to take disciplinary proceedings against the respondent and handed over a charge-sheet to him. The respondent was also suspended from the bank's service.

Thereafter an enquiry was conducted against the respondent. The enquiry officer came to the conclusion that the two charges framed against the respondent had been proved and recommended after taking into consideration the past service and conduct of the respondent that he should be discharged from the service of the bank.

Thereafter according to the rules prevalent in the bank the respondent was given notice to show cause why he should not be discharged. His explanation was taken into account and thereafter the bank decided to discharge him.
On December 27, 1961, the bank applied under s. 33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act, No. 14 of 1947, for approval of the action proposed to be taken against the respondent.
After this application was made, the bank's case is that it actually discharged the respondent on January 15, 1962.

The application under s. 33(2)(b) finally came up for disposal before the labour court. That court held relying on a decision of this Court in Strawboard Manufacturing Co. v. Gobind that as the application had been made for approval of the proposed discharge and before the actual discharge of the respondent, it was not maintainable. Consequently it dismissed the bank's prayer for approval of the proposed action.
Appeal by special leave from the order dated September 20, 1962, of the Central Government Labour Court at Dhanbad in Application No. L.C. 113 of 1962.
The respondent could not appear before the labour court on the date on which it decided the matter, on the ground that he was ill. He had submitted a medical certificate in that connection.
The respondent had filed a written statement in reply to the bank's application in which he controverted the facts on which he was ordered to be discharged.

legal_issues.text: Whether an application under s. 33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act is maintainable if made by the employer for approval of the proposed action (discharge) before the actual action is taken.
Whether approval should be granted to the action proposed by the bank, considering if the enquiry was properly conducted, bona fide, and not due to victimisation or unfair labour practice.

petitioner_arguments.text: The labour court was not right in holding that the application was not maintainable on the ground that it had been made for approval of the proposed action and not after the action had been taken. The decision in Strawboard Manufacturing Co. v. Gobind has been misunderstood.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. v. Gobind; s. 33(2)(b) Industrial Disputes Act

petitioner_arguments.text: The enquiry was properly conducted, and the proposed action was bona fide, not due to victimisation or unfair labour practice.

respondent_arguments.text: The application under s. 33(2)(b) was not maintainable as it was made for approval of proposed discharge before actual discharge.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. v. Gobind; s. 33(2)(b) Industrial Disputes Act

respondent_arguments.text: In written statement, controverted the facts, alleged enquiry was a pretence, in disregard of natural justice, and victimisation.
Prayed for remand to labour court to enable appearance due to illness.

court_reasoning.text: The contention that Strawboard case requires application after action is taken is incorrect. Strawboard negatived the view that application must be before action; it allows after action as part of same transaction. Nothing prevents application before action for proposed action.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 33(2)(b) does not require application only after action; pre-action application is maintainable and favourable to employee.

court_reasoning.text: No remand needed as written statement filed, matter pending since 1961. Examined enquiry papers: enquiry proper, no victimisation or unfair practice. Respondent's allegations bare, no specifics.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Enquiry fair, in accordance with natural justice; full opportunity to defend.

holdings.text: Application under s. 33(2)(b) for approval of proposed action before actual action is maintainable.
Enquiry was properly conducted, bona fide, no victimisation or unfair labour practice; approval granted to proposed discharge.

precedents_cited.relevance: Clarified that it does not require application under s.33(2)(b) only after action taken; allows post-action as same transaction, but pre-action also permissible.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires employer approval for discharge during pendency of dispute; application maintainable for proposed action before or after taking action.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; labour court order set aside; bank's application under s.33(2)(b) dated Dec 27, 1961 granted; proposed action (discharge) approved.

key_quotes.text: "We see nothing in principle against the employer making an application under s. 33(2)(b) for approval of the proposed action before the actual action is taken."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on maintainability of pre-action application.

key_quotes.text: "All that the Strawboard Manufacturing Co.'s case lays down is that the application can be made after the action of which the approval is sought has been taken and that when this happens the three conditions in the proviso to s. 33(2)(b) must be shown to be parts of the same transaction."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We are therefore of opinion that the labour court was wrong in holding that an application made by an employer under s. 33(2)(b) for approval of the action he proposes to take is not entertainable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
